messages.content: Syntax is a podcast about web development. Available at https://Syntax.fm
This episode is #456 entitled 10 Nifty Browser APIs

Summarize the provided podcast transcript into very succinct bullet points, each containing just a few words. The bullet points should correspond to different sections or topics discussed in the podcast. Include any opinions the hosts have.

Remember, the key here is to read through the transcript carefully, identify the main points or topics, and then condense each one into a very brief, clear statement. It's also important to include timestamps if they're provided in the transcript, as they can help give a sense of the flow and structure of the podcast.

Additionally, Please create the following for this podcast episode:

1. 1-2 sentence description about what is covered in the podcast. This should be a short, catchy, and interesting description. It should provoke the listener to stop what they are doing and listen to the podcast.
1. 6-7 tweets for this podcast episode. These tweets should be short, catchy, and interesting. They should provoke the twitter user to respond an join in the conversation. Don't use any hash tags or emojis.
2. 6-7 tweets about this podcast that can be tweeted by listeners of the show. Some examples are "This is a fantastic episode about ___", or "I really enjoyed the part about ____"
3. 3-4 hashtags that categorize the episode. these will be used as topic tags on the website.
4. A summary of the podcast into a title. It should be catchy, slightly click-baity, and make the listener want to stop what they are doing and watch it.
5. Keep track of any links or websites mentioned in the podcast. These will be used as links on the website. If you can't find the link, provide only the name of the website.
6. tally the time each speaker speaks. This will be used to create a pie chart of who speaks the most.
7. For each speaker and topic, report sentiment analysis for positive, neutral, negative amd uncertain
8. Provide a MidJourney prompt to create artwork for the podcast

You may exclude transcripts from the Announcer and ad-reads from sponsors, unless the sponsor is Sentry.

Return each of these things in JSON format that looks like this:

{
  "title": "...",
  description: "...",
  "summary": [{time: '02:33', text: "..."}],
  "tweets: ["..."],
  "listener_tweets": ["..."],
  topics: ["...", "..."],
  links: [{ name: 'Name of link', url: 'https://example.com"}, "..."],
  speaker_times: [{name: 'Wes Bos', time: '02:33'}, "..."],
  sentiment_analysis: [{ topic: 'JavaScript', speaker: 'Wes Bos', sentiment: 'positive'}, ...],

}

00:00 Wes Bos:
Let's get ready to syntax.

00:04 Announcer:
Listen to Syntax, the top web development podcast with Scott Zelensky and West Boss. Strap in and enjoy!

00:14 Wes Bos:
Welcome to the tastiest web development podcast, discussing browser APIs or vanilla JavaScript/web APIs. We'll explore 10 nifty things you can do in the browser and their uses. We are sponsored by Prismic, Log Rocket, and Freshbooks, which we'll discuss later. I'm West Bos, a Canadian developer, and joining me is Scott Tolinski. How are you doing today?

01:02 Announcer:
I'm doing good. Loving our new dishwasher, as I'd been hand washing our kids' dishes for 1.5 hours every night for around 8878 months since moving in. Now I can put the kids to bed with Courtney, so I'm in a good mood. Everything else, like ESLint, is fine.

01:40 Wes Bos:
That dishwasher you purchased is amazing. I unloaded ours in the dark, but yours has built-in lights!

01:51 Announcer:
Seems like a spaceship when opened. Astonishing. The coolest thing is the dishwasher's easy sliding drawers. Unlike washer drawers, these are almost too smooth. I'm a fan. Had a good week here. Dishwasher talk.

02:21 Wes Bos:
Someone tweeted they enjoy our podcast as we don't discuss olive oil initially. But, we might actually do that.

02:31 Announcer:
It feels like something we might actually do, and I'm pretty sure we've done that. I've been doing outdoor landscaping work this weekend, like cutting down a giant tree by myself near a power line. It was leaning, and I hoped the wind would knock it down, but it just leaned more. I decided to handle it, as a developer would, one step at a time. I knew where I wanted it to fall, followed YouTube instructions, cut the wedges, and a 15-20 foot tree landed exactly where I planned. I'm very impressed with myself, and that's good.

03:37 Wes Bos:
I often watch tree disasters, like them falling on houses. Ever received hate? I posted a tree falling on Instagram and got so much hate, even though we have thousands of trees on our property. People were upset about removing a fine tree that would eventually rot.

03:57 Announcer:
Oh, no hate, but I had to preemptively tackle this issue. The tree was growing into power lines and shouldn't have been planted there. It had a major lean and was a disaster waiting to happen, even though still alive. I didn't want it falling on our patio furniture, a kid, or the dog. So I took it down. We have a literal forest, so one tree won't make a difference. Alright, let's get into our 10 items. First is

04:35 Wes Bos:
Many of you have likely used Get user media, a browser API that accesses user media like webcams and microphones. There are additional APIs that let you access multiple cameras simultaneously. Check out hair.wesbos.com, where I created an app displaying multiple webcams at once. I had nine webcams working together, and you can see their names as well as the front or back designation on mobile devices. I even tested it on my car's head unit, which recognized the dash cam as a wheel cam but crashed after some time.

05:53 Announcer:
kinda interesting. Is is your dash cam, like, integrated into the car?

05:57 Wes Bos:
No, the dash cam is separate but has a USB interface for power and viewing. The head unit I bought has an app to review dashcam footage. It's smart enough to communicate with the USB dash cam, likely similar to a webcam.

06:21 Announcer:
Yeah, there's so much to do with getUserMedia Vercel—lots of fun stuff. I think we need more fun side projects where you take the webcam feed, pipe it to a canvas, apply effects and play with pixels. It's not just about building practical Zoom alternatives. Check out my JavaScript 30 course for ideas.

06:56 Wes Bos:
We build lots of enjoyable things using the webcam by taking its feed, known as a source object, and placing it into a video element. Once in the video element, it's like a Pnpm or JPEG, which can be transferred to a canvas element. From there, the possibilities are endless, with access to every pixel.

07:22 Announcer:
Yeah, there's lots of potential in newer APIs like the File System API. I recently did a course on this, which is why I'm so familiar with it. The File System API allows access to reading files, directories, and writing files. In our course, we built an SVG editor in under 40 lines of code. It saves directly to your local file system instead of downloading a new file or zip like previous file editors.

With a file or directory picker, you get access to handles, which can either be a file or directory type. You can modify and save a file with a permissions popup in the browser. It's surprisingly simple to use - under 40 lines of vanilla JS for a basic file editor.

However, compatibility is the biggest issue since it mainly works with Chromium-based browsers and has limited support in Safari. There's no support in Firefox or Internet Explorer. If you're building an electron app using Chrome, you can take advantage of this API for some impressive functionality.

11:10 Wes Bos:
That's interesting, but not a huge Deno issue, as many file system API use cases involve electron applications, which only run in Chrome environments. According to MDN, this interface won't grant access to user's file system but provides a virtual drive within the browser sandbox. To access user's file system, you need to involve the user, like installing a Chrome extension. It seems usable in Firefox, but only read-only and within a sandbox.

This becomes tricky when crossing from the browser sandbox to user's computer, as potential security issues arise, enabling access to user's files. This concern over safety is why websites are secure and why iPhones avoided Flash, as it's a third-party program that runs locally on devices instead of the browser, accessing the entire computer's file system.

12:39 Announcer:
Possible security issue there. Windows file, common troll to delete system 32. Could have a delayed system, yes.

12:54 Wes Bos:
Let's discuss geolocation in ad breaks, an API that's been around for 12 years. With navigator.geolocation, you can watch the current position or just get the location once, useful for maps or zoning in without needing postal codes. However, it's annoying when websites immediately ask for location access. Ideally, they should request it when finding the nearest store or similar. Denying access can make unblocking geolocation difficult for regular users, as the UI is often confusing, especially on mobile.

14:04 Announcer:
I was on Home Depot's website last night, and it's funny you mention it because they were asking my location, activities, and company. I didn't want to share that info - so weird how they ask such personal questions.

14:26 Wes Bos:
It's uncomfortable when a website prompts you as soon as you open it. For example, when visiting Home Depot's website, it tells me the closest store is in Niagara Falls, even though I haven't given it access to my location. They can estimate the location using server-side info but should ask for access to get more accurate results. So, Home Depot should improve this aspect.

15:04 Announcer:
Data back in CMS's. Why aren't you so cool like 1 of our sponsors today, Prism.

15:11 Wes Bos:
Yes, Prismic is a headless CMS that enhances websites through rapid creation of on-brand pages using reusable website sections, or slices. It focuses on mapping data pieces to components, allowing for versatile page assembly with various data types like users and food. Using any front-end framework, you can create slices in Prismic and connect them into a single page via the UI, promoting growth and marketing flexibility.

Prismic.IO/syntax is great from both UI and developer perspectives. Thanks, Prismic, for sponsoring. Next, we'll discuss the permissions API. West, have you looked at it? It involves access to features like notifications.

17:08 Announcer:
The Permissions API allows you to check if you have permission to use certain features before proceeding. It's supported by a few notable APIs like clipboard, notifications, push API, and WebMedI. However, this API has poor support and is difficult to implement consistently across browsers. It allows checking user permissions statuses in JavaScript in the browser, but caution is advised due to its varied support. This API might tempt you, but it's frustrating to utilize effectively.

18:50 Wes Bos:
Yeah, it's frustrating on the web when someone says no to a permission, as you often have no API to fix it, especially for the clipboard and other notifications. This can be annoying for users when they need to grant access to features like the webcam for important tasks, such as taking a photo of a driver's license.

Undoing that decision can be difficult, especially on mobile. Many apps first use their own UI to ask for access before prompting the user. You typically only have one shot to ask for access, which can be challenging even for technical users trying to figure out how to reverse those choices.

19:54 Announcer:
how do I change this setting?

Yeah, what's up with the cop icon? You have to scroll through 40 apps to find it, which is annoying. Programmatically doing it could lead to misuse, like constant pop-ups. It's like ad blocking, where pop-ups have good uses but can be abused. They had to tie pop-ups to real clicks. Remember when pop-up blockers were a big issue?

20:36 Announcer:
I sometimes watch pirated sports content, like the Colorado Avalon games in Denver, which are blacked out if you don't have Comcast. To watch my local hockey team, I visit shady websites, particularly on iOS, and deal with countless pop-ups constantly flying at me and opening new tabs on the iPad. Pop-ups are definitely still an issue for me. It's crazy.

21:15 Wes Bos:
Yeah, Permissions API. One of those. Think it'll improve? Still in progress? Will it eventually support?

21:24 Announcer:
Today, we're discussing Chrome's excellent support for various APIs, as evident by the green check marks. It's a no-brainer for browsers like Firefox and Safari, including iOS Safari and Android web view, to improve their support for features like permission access and query permissions. However, it's disheartening to see the same pattern of limited support in these browsers. Despite some APIs having experimental flags or caution signs, the permissions API is particularly useful and desired.

22:36 Wes Bos:
But you can't. So, next up, I'll let you discuss this, as it's your favorite. I haven't used it directly, but I've utilized things that use the web animation API. Sometimes I just browse MDN docs and think, wow, what a different world. So, web animations.

23:00 Announcer:
The Web Animations API is a method for constructing animations using JavaScript without diving into CSS animations or transitions. It allows you to create an animation and control its playback, such as play, pause, reverse, and update the playback rate. Unlike CSS animations, you have to create the animation and then trigger it using an event or call in JavaScript.

The Web Animations API is good because it doesn't require a library but falls short compared to browser frameworks like Framer Motion and installed animations. The creator of Framer Motion introduces Motion 1, a library that simplifies the Web Animations API and offers a smaller library size, working with everything.

Motion 1 uses TypeScript to apply CSS properties and interpolate spring values, making it more lightweight than Framer Motion while still supporting various functionalities. The website also features an appealing deep blue, yellow, and black color scheme.

25:46 Wes Bos:
Wow, the Web Animations API can be frustrating, but it's meant to be built on top of, like primitives in the browser. Nice layers can be created on top of it, similar to fetch, which is ergonomic to use directly. Some audio APIs are also frustrating, but can have great layers built on them.

Next up is the Resize Observer API, a favorite and used in commerce talks and personal websites. Use it to know when an element's width, height, or position changes on the page. Previously, only window resizing could be listened for. An example is a video player and a list of videos adjusting their sizes based on personal preference.

Similar to container queries, you can use TypeScript to know when an element's size changes programmatically. Handy for determining if an element is on screen, or pausing/playing a video based on scrolling position.

28:10 Announcer:
Yes, we use container queries by creating a Sfeldt action that assigns classes based on browser width, using minimal code. We implemented a new resize observer to get the current node's width and alter its classes according to the provided dimensions array. This efficient method is under 20 lines of code and proves resize observer is a viable approach. Although it can be performance-heavy, we've used it on all cards in a large grid without issues. Overall, haven't encountered problems with resize observer.

29:10 Wes Bos:
alternative: check every 300ms for changes. Browser knows when elements are on/off page, and when they're bigger/smaller since it paints them. So who better to inform of changes than the device that is

29:31 Announcer:
Painting rectangles on browsers and using various APIs might lead to errors. A solution to stay aware, such as Log Rocket, could help you by providing a video replay of what exactly broke your site, error logs, and user experiences. Log Rocket offers new features and tools to improve user experiences on your websites by stopping guesswork on bug occurrences, tracking customer engagement with heatmaps, and making data-driven design decisions.

The Clipboard API enables copying and pasting features, including images, depending on browser support. Copying text is widely supported except for Internet Explorer. To utilize this, simply use 'navigator.clipboard.readText' along with some text, and it returns a promise. You can also write text through event-triggered actions like paste buttons. However, pasting requires user permission, given its invasiveness, before accessing the clipboard. The API can handle media but has limited support. The basic copying and pasting of text are easily implemented using 'navigator.clipboard.readText'.

32:38 Wes Bos:
Our coupon dashboard enables copying coupons programmatically for 20% off, $10 off, etc., without needing a function, just an onclick handler. I wonder if you can tell if something's in someone's clipboard, like iPhone apps that detect a 1-time password and offer to paste it - a convenient feature to avoid holding and waiting for the bubble.

33:32 Announcer:
You just read the text. I've swapped "read" with "write" several times in the past minute. If I did that, then yes, it can read your text with permission. It will prompt you with a browser notification, requesting access to your clipboard. After reading, it checks if it matches a specific type like 6 numbers. Does it resemble a bank account? Copy this. Beautiful.

34:12 Wes Bos:
Next, we have Bos storageAPI, including both session storage and local storage. Local storage is widely used as a key-value store for text only. To store objects, numbers, etc., it's best to store them as JSON to maintain structure and types. There's also session storage. What distinguishes local from session storage, Scott? Session storage

34:51 Announcer:
Essentially, session storage disappears when the session ends (browser or tab closes), while local storage remains. The interface for both is the same, just using "session storage" instead of "local storage." Storing something in session storage means it's gone once the tab is closed. Personally, I don't use session storage and would be curious about its use cases.

35:32 Wes Bos:
Yeah, it'd be useful if library computers, used repeatedly by different people, didn't store data like cookies to prevent possible login issues. Most libraries have a wipe sequence to clean the system, but not all. This is a good use case.

previously on Scott. My kids are learning the wipe sequence right now. That's That's a good 1.

It was frustrating, but they fixed it. There are still websites that don't allow new tabs though. Web storage is interesting for storing data locally, almost like a small database. It's useful for temporarily saving something, like filling out a form.

37:06 Announcer:

38:20 Announcer:

I remember making the Mac talk was entertaining, but now it's effortless in browsers with various uses. For example, I built a dance app that randomly shouted dance moves to help learn different sequences, which was easy to implement.

39:56 Wes Bos:

With just six lines of code, you can make something that speaks back to you. Truly empowering!

feed. It's speech to text, not text to speech. Yes, what did I say? Maybe the opposite, or I heard the opposite. Okay, it's what you're saying to text.

A game called Bos Speech Colors was created, with players quickly saying CSS colors to progress. Sadly, it doesn't work in Firefox or Opera, but works well in Chrome, Edge, and Safari. Grammars are a property of the speech recognition interface, returning understood collections. In an example, the grammars given were color names.
